poem:
**The Echo of Scales**  

The hum of water learns my name,  
childhood ripples in memory's stream.  
A quiet fairground's prize, now dreams  
that shimmer where canals once ran.  
Banbury skies feathered with clouds,  
hooked on time's finned journey.  
The scales glint as echoes hold  
a promise of gold, blinking slow  
within this circle of life.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Experience: I caught the ‘world’s biggest goldfish’ I won my first goldfish at a fair. I was young and I can’t remember what I had to do to win it or what I called it, but I spent hours watching him swim around the little plastic tank in my room. From then on, I was hooked on fish. When I turned eight, my dad would take me float fishing in the canal near where we lived in Banbury, Oxfordshire. I was ecstatic". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
